span: Alight, so option A, the sun is up [the star is lit up], and has some upright triangles, and then the blue and green ones are slanted.
summary: Describes star and orientations in A

span: Option B has a slanted triangle and everything else is upright.
Option C has slanted red triangles and a slanted green triangle, and the others are upright.
summary: Observes slanted red and green in C

span: Option D has a bunch of triangles that are slanted and some that are upright.
Option E has an upside-down one and then three triangles that are upright.
summary: Notes upside-down plus upright in E

span: And then option F has a lot of different types of triangles in different positions.
The colors are pretty different, seems like… um… (3.0).
So I guess… (4.0) yeah, I don’t really see any clear similarities at first glance.
I was looking at the red triangles and how they were slanted — like in C and F — but in A they’re upright.
summary: Finds red-slant idea contradicted by A

span: In option F the triangle is upright, and in option A as well, but in option C it’s slanted.
Option F has an upside-down one, but the other ones don’t.
summary: Notes unique upside-down triangle in F

span: And then Option A, option C, and option F have triangles that are stacked on each other, but they’re different colors.
summary: Observes stacking across A, C, F

span: So I guess that could potentially be the hidden rule — is that there have to be triangles that stacked on top of each other in all of them because nothing else really sticks out too much besides that.
So that would be my guess: that options A, option C, and option F have triangles that are stacked on each other.
Yeah, I don’t see any other similarities besides that.
